newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: Ivorian coffee farm price may rise 97/98-minister.
newsitem.headline: Ivorian coffee farm price may rise 97/98-minister.

text.p: Ivory Coast is considering raising its reference coffee farmgate price for 1997/98 (Oct-Sept) above 500 CFA francs a kilo following world price rises in 1996/97, Agriculture minister Lambert Kouassi Konan said in an interview.
"It is likely that the next season will open with a higher reference price," he was quoted as saying by Paris-based magazine Jeune Afrique in an interview published on Wednesday.
"At the moment, coffee prices are heading up," he added.
Ivory Coast's state Caistab marketing board opened its 1996/97 coffee season late with a farmgate price 200 CFA francs down at 500 CFA francs, including a five CFA per kilo allowance for jute bags.
The Caistab lost money in 1995/96 as prices fell after farm-to-port marketing prices had been set high at 700 CFA francs a kilo.
Ivory Coast forecast a crop of 230,000 tonnes for 1996/97 but port arrivals already total over 300,000 tonnes, the highest since the early 1980s and well above the 180,000 tonnes in 1996/97.
Koussi said prices could fall below reference levels if harvests were large.
A secondary market paying above reference coffee prices developed during the smaller harvest in 1995/96, he said.
Ivory Coast has loosened its monopoly on cocoa and coffee marketing since 1995 under terms for a $150 million agriculture credit from the World Bank -- which wants further changes.
Cocoa and coffee liberalisation are on a wider agenda for aid talks with the International Monetary Fund next week on a three-year economic plan for Ivory Coast.
Donors want the state Caistab commodities board to hand farm-to-port price-setting to the private sector, with exporters possibly assuming a greater role in export auction management.
Ivory Coast has agreed to sweeping coffee marketing reforms from 1998/99, and some for cocoa from 1999/2000, but full details have yet to be decided.
